intro: Hesperidopsis integrifolius, commonly known as the desert flax, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its slender, branching stems and small, clustered white or yellowish flowers. The plant has pinnately compound leaves with smooth, entire margins, and it produces small, oval-shaped fruits known as schizocarps. Hesperidopsis integrifolius is well adapted to drought conditions, with a deep root system and a slow growth rate that helps it survive in harsh, desert environments.
